Package edu.missouri.geom

Class Line

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mmkrusniak.geom.Line
  • public class Line
extends java.lang.Object
    A geometric object representing a line segment, ray, or infinite line. All lines are defined by two points, though defining a line as a ray or an infinite line affects calculations involving it, and except for a few exceptions noted below those details are mostly abstracted. Like all geometric objects, lines are immutable; once defined they may not be changed.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Line

        public Line​(Point a,
            Point b)
        Construct a line segment defined by the two points at which it ends.
        Parameters:
        a - The first endpoint of the segment.
        b - The second endpoint of the segment.

      • Line

        public Line​(Point a,
            Point b,
            int type)
        Construct a line that passes through two points. It can be a segment (ends at both points), a ray (ends at the first point but extends infinitely out of the second point), or an infinite line (extends infinitely out of both points). This does mean that there are multiple ways of instantiating a ray or an infinite line - for instance, an infinite line through (0, 0) and (1, 1) is the same as an infinite line through (2, 2) and (3, 3).
        Parameters:
        a - The first point by which the line is defined (an endpoint if it's to be a line segment or ray).
        b - The second point by which the line is defined (an endpoint if t's to be a line segment).
        type - The type of line to construct; one of SEGMENT, INFINITE, or RAY.

      • Line

        public Line​(Line l,
            int type)
        Construct a line identical to another line, but which is a different type. For example, extends a segment to a ray.
        Parameters:
        l - A line.
        type - A line type; one of SEGMENT, INFINITE, or RAY.

      • Line

        public Line​(Point a,
            double m,
            int type)
        Construct a line (either a ray or an infinite line) from a point and a slope. If it's a ray, the point is its endpoint. Line segments can't be constructed in this way.
        Parameters:
        a - A point.
        m - A slope for the line to have. (Remember that the coordinate system has Y facing down, so a positive slope generates a downwards-tilting line graphically speaking.)
        type - A line type, either INFINITE or RAY.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If used to instantiate a line segment.

      • parallelTo

        public static Line parallelTo​(Line l,
                              Point p)
        Gives an infinite line which is parallel to the given line and passes through the given point.
        Parameters:
        l - A line.
        p - A point.
        Returns:
        A line parallel to the given line passing through the given point.

        p - A point.
        Returns:

      • getType

        public int getType()
        Gives the type of this Line - infinite line, ray or segment. @return The type of this Line.

      • dx

        public double dx()
        Gives the Cartesian X distance spanned by the points defining this line (so rays and infinite lines also have finite distance). @return The change in X on this line.

      • dy

        public double dy()
        Gives the Cartesian Y distance spanned by the points defining this line (so rays and infinite lines also have finite distance). @return The change in Y on this line.

      • dz

        public double dz()
        Gives the Cartesian Z distance spanned by the points defining this line (so rays and infinite lines also have finite distance). @return The change in Z on this line.

      • dn

        public double dn​(int n)
        Gives the nth Cartesian distance spanned by the points defining this line (so rays and infinite lines also have finite distance). @return The change in the nth dimension on this line.

      • a

        public Point a()
        Gives the first point defining this line. @return The first point defining this line.

      • b

        public Point b()
        Gives the second point defining this line. @return The second point defining this line.

      • intersection

        public Point intersection​(Line l)
        Gives the intersection of this line with another. The implementation uses Cramer's Rule.
        Parameters:
        l - Another line.
        Returns:
        The intersection of that line with this one, or null if they do not intersect.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Formats this line as a string. The format is (%.2f, %.2f, %.2f)-(%.2f, %.2f, %.2f). Note that this does not indicate the type of line.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        The line as a string.

      • render

        public void render​(java.awt.Graphics g)
        Renders this line on a Java graphics canvas. Infinite lines and rays are drawn to extreme coordinates in lieu of infinite ones.
        Parameters:
        g - A Java graphics canvas.

      • toSubpoints

        public java.util.Collection<? extends Point> toSubpoints​(double segLength)
        Splits this line into subpoints, where each one is a distance apart on the line. There may be a remainder, so one point might be somewhat closer than the others.
        Parameters:
        segLength - The length apart to create the subpoints.
        Returns:
        A list of points which all lie on the line and all of which (except one) are that length apart.

      • midpoint

        public Point midpoint()
        Gives the midpoint of the line.
        Returns:
        The midpoint of the line.

      • rotate

        public Line rotate​(double theta)
        Rotates the line around its midpoint.
        Parameters:
        theta - Amount to rotate.
        Returns:
        A line which represents this line after being rotated.

      • contains

        public boolean contains​(Point p)
        Gives whether a point lies on (or near) the line. The granularity used is Point.GRANULARITY.
        Parameters:
        p - A point.
        Returns:
        Whether that point lies on the line.

      • arrayFromPoints

        public static Line[] arrayFromPoints​(Point[] points)
        Generates an array of Lines that form a path through a list of points in order. It does not loop, merely stopping at the final point.
        Parameters:
        points - A list of points.
        Returns:
        An array of Lines that forms a path through the given list of points.
